speaker: Neil
text: Hello, I'm Neil. And welcome to 6 Minute English, where we bring you an interesting topic and six related items of vocabulary. But … there should be two of us … and my co-presenter Rob hasn't arrived … Rob? …. Rob! … You're late!

speaker: Rob
text: Am I? What's the time?

speaker: Neil
text: It's time to start the show. Do you actually own a watch?

speaker: Rob
text: No. I rely on my internal clock – it's pretty good.

speaker: Neil
text: No, it isn't – you're late!

speaker: Rob
text: But I'm usually on time. Now today, we're talking about what would happen to the world if all the clocks stopped.

speaker: Neil
text: It seems like that wouldn't worry you much, Rob.

speaker: Rob
text: You're right. I think we're slaves to time – we've got digital clocks on everything – smartphones, computers, microwaves, bus stops – it's hard to get away from it. Did you know the word time is the most common noun in the English language, according to the Oxford English Dictionary?

speaker: Neil
text: Oh, well, I didn't know that, Rob! But good timekeeping is extremely important – there are so many things to schedule in a day, and so many deadlines to meet…

speaker: run out of time
text: Tick… tock… tick… tock… Well, before we run out of time Neil – and that means use it all up – let's have a quiz question. Can you tell me what the word 'clock' originally referred to? Is it …

speaker: run out of time
text: a) a pendulum,

speaker: run out of time
text: b) a bell or

speaker: run out of time
text: c) a dial?

speaker: pendulumdial
text: A pendulum is a stick with a weight on the end that swings regularly from side to side. And a dial is the round part of a clock, but there are dials on loads of things – they aren't just on clocks. And a bell… is… well…  a bell!

speaker: Rob
text: Well, hurry up, Neil – you're wasting time with all these explanations!

speaker: Neil
text: That's cheeky coming from you, Rob. I think the answer is probably 'bell'.

speaker: Rob
text: Well, you could be right – because not all timepieces go tick tock. In fact, mechanical clocks and watches are quite recent in the history of timekeeping.

speaker: Mechanical
text: Mechanical means to do with machines. So in the past, before people had mechanical timepieces, how did they know when to arrive at work, for example – or when to finish?

speaker: Rob
text: They would have looked up at the sky, and observed how the position of the sun, the moon, and the stars changed as time passed.

speaker: Neil
text: That doesn't sound very precise!

speaker: Precise
text: Precise means accurate or exact. It was precise enough for many people. Let's listen to the Director of the Museum of the History of Science in Oxford, Dr Silke Ackermann talking about this.

speaker: Dr Silke Ackermann, Director of the Museum of the History of Science in Oxford
text: We certainly gain precision but we completely get devolved or divorced from where time originally came from. The time we use was based on the movement of the sun and it's roughly still in sync but… for many societies it wasn't at all relevant to know that it's four o'clock. They needed to know how much daylight have I got left, or when is the prayer time I need to observe for completely different reasons, and whilst precision is wonderful it's also very much a straitjacket. Everybody is dominated by… looking at the watch and smartphone all the time, when we observe people. So we basically became a slave to time.

speaker: Neil
text: So in the past, they had different reasons for wanting to know the time, is that it?

speaker: Rob
text: Yes – in ancient times, people were concerned about the changing of the seasons and how this affected them. When it was time to plants crops, or when to harvest them. When the rainy season was going to start…

speaker: Neil
text: Now you mention it, in the Muslim world, the start of Ramadan is traditionally calculated by the rising of the crescent moon – which changes every year. And you can't calculate that with modern methods of timekeeping.

speaker: straitjacket
text: You're catching on, Neil! Now, what does Dr Ackermann mean when she says precision is a straitjacket?

speaker: Neil
text: She means that always wanting to be precise about time can limit what we do in a way that is damaging.

speaker: Rob
text: So we need to take our time – relax a bit… That's my philosophy for life.

speaker: Neil
text: But we are seriously running out of time now, Rob – so please hurry up and tell us the answer to today's quiz question.

speaker: Rob
text: OK. Well, the answer is bell. So, you were right, Neil! The word clock is derived from the Celtic words clagan and clocca meaning "bell". A silent instrument that doesn't have a bell has traditionally been known as a timepiece. But today a "clock" refers to any device for measuring and displaying the time.

speaker: Neil
text: Well, moving quickly on, let's go through the words we learned today. First up was 'run out of time' – or use it all up. You can run out of pretty much anything…

speaker: Rob
text: 'Oh no! We've run out of sugar! Who's going to the shops to buy some more?'

speaker: Neil
text: Number two – 'pendulum' – a stick with a weight on the end that swings regularly from side to side, controlling the movement of a clock.

speaker: Rob
text: 'The pendulum on my Grandfather Clock has stopped swinging.'

speaker: Neil
text: Sorry to hear that, Rob. Number three – a 'dial' is the round part of a clock. But more generally, it refers to a round instrument that shows you the amount of something, for example, heat, pressure or speed.

speaker: Rob
text: 'The hands moved slowly round the clock dial.'

speaker: Neil
text: Phones used to have dials that you turned to make a phone call. Here's the verb: 'I dialled his number but he didn't answer.'

speaker: Rob
text: Alfred Hitchcock made a film called 'Dial M for Murder'! OK – number four is 'mechanical' – to do with machines. 'Our plane was delayed because of a mechanical problem.'

speaker: Neil
text: Number five – 'precise' – which means accurate and exact. So 'What type of mechanical problem? Could you be more precise, Rob?'

speaker: Rob
text: No, I don't have time, Neil! Number six is 'straitjacket'.

speaker: Neil
text: Which means limiting what somebody can do in a way that is damaging. It's also a jacket with long arms that are tied behind a person to stop them from behaving violently.

speaker: Rob
text: 'Oh, no, not the straitjacket! I promise I'll behave myself, Neil.'

speaker: Neil
text: OK, if you really promise, Rob.

speaker: Rob
text: Right. Well, we've run out of time! Please check out our Instagram, Twitter, Facebook and YouTube pages.

speaker: Neil
text: Goodbye!

speaker: Rob
text: Bye-bye!
